reviewText: Fantastic Contraption is interesting but isn't a fun" game. If it came with your Vive
recommended: knock yourself out. The pure experience of playing in virtual reality should be enough to keep you engaged for hours
hoursPlayed: even if you aren't really having "fun". Otherwise
voteText: the asking price is outrageous and you should wait until it's on a deep sale.\n\nWhere the game falters is in the extremely limited pool of parts to build from. There are basically only two parts
helpfulPercent: wheels and beams. There are technically two types of beams
votesHelpful: but the distinction rarely matters. Using these tools
votesTotal: you complete simple puzzles by building simple machines. You cannot control your vehicle in any way
votesFunny: so getting it to do what you want involves either making a vehicle that moves straight and pointing it in the right direction
commentsCount: or designing it so that it moves in a curve - and pointing it in the right direction. You're so limited it's hard to be clever
column16: and most puzzles come down to trial and error of adjusting the lengths of the beams until the vehicle moves just right.\n\nIn some cases it's easier not to make a contraption at all. I beat one level
column17: where I needed to put a pink ball inside a pink cube that was far away
column18: by attaching the ball to the end of a very long pole
column19: swinging the pole around so that the ball was already inside the cube
column20: and starting the level. The game pretends like you can only build within a limited area
column21: but in reality you can make your parts as big as you want
column22: and there's nothing to stop you from making a pole that stretches across the entire level.\n\nThe gameplay is very similar to Besiege
column23: but with most of the features removed (though Besiege may have copied its gameplay from the original Fantastic Contraption 2D game). If you've played Besiege
column24: you will find the gameplay of Fantastic Contraption much less intriguing. You may have loved the original 2D Fantastic Contraption
column25: but the gameplay simply does not translate well to 3D.\n\nFC has the worst menu ever designed by anyone. The person who designed the menu is a psycopath. You access the menu by putting on a helmet in the game
column26: instead of pressing the menu button on the Vive controller like a sane developer would expect you to do. The menu itself is a cluster of complex 3D objects all jammed tightly together
column27: so that if you don't have a large play area you will literally be stuck inside the objects that make up the menu and unable to see them clearly. The menu uses strange physics-based design - for example
column29: you pick up a tiny copy of it off of a table and drop it onto a spinning plate. The fact that the plate spins freely makes this difficult
column30: and if you drop the piece it can bounce out of reach and now you aren't allowed to save your contraption. I think you are also supposed to be able to change levels from this menu
column31: but I have no idea how. I can grab levels from another spinning plate and throw them at the walls
column32: but I don't see a way to activate one. The menu is incredibly stupid
column33: and the devs need to accept that it was a bad decision and abandon it instead of sticking with it just because they put time into it.\n\nDespite the gameplay not being very good
column34: the game is definitely engaging just because the experience of building a contraption by hand in VR is so new. The construction gameplay is very satisfying - it's easy to maneuver pieces exactly the way you want and the fact that you can be doing a separate thing with each hand is awesome. I get the impression that the developers got so caught up in the building mechanics that they forgot to come up with a fun gameplay concept.\n\nIf you got FC for free it will probably tide you over until you buy something enjoyable
column35: but I definitely wouldn't recommend spending money on it. This game isn't even remotely worth $40. This is a $5 experience."

Typically I don't enjoy contraption type games on a 2D monitor, but in Vr with hand tracking, it's like you're a wizard that can bring to life what ever type of contraption yo uwant to build. highly recomended.

reviewText:
I was pretty excited about this game… and, if you got this game came in the Vive bundle, then it's pretty cool to have just for the experience of building things in Virtual Reality.

But I have to say that the purchase price for the game is way out of proportion for what you actually get.

I was hoping for a VR version of Besieged (which is incredibly entertaining); but Fantastic Contraptions feels like a very watered down version that does not allow you to build anything really creatively useful to fulfilling the in-game goals. That saps all the fun right out of it.

The Virtual Reality part is done very well. It feels flawless and intuitive to move around in the environment, grab things, and put them together using both hands. But the gameplay does not feel complete. It seems as though Fantastic Contraption has the basics down (beams, wheels, building with two hands, VR environment) but is missing elements of gameplay to allow you to focus more on creativity rather than simply fiddling with basics to make the contraptions work properly.

A good example of this is that there is no way, as far as I can tell, to snap your wheels to be properly straight and aligned with one another. Because it's pretty much impossible for you to lay the wheels down perfectly straight by hand, your contraptions are often going to slowly turn one direction or another. You have to keep restarting the level and slightly twisting a wheel one direction or another until it works right. I'd rather spend my time trying to figure out a creative way to make my contraptions do the intended job than to mess around trying to get the basics to work (i.e. making the contraption drive straight).

To use Besieged as an example again, in Besieged there are so many fundamentally different ways to achieve the end goal that if you and a friend play it at the same time, it’s unlikely that your vehicles will look anything alike. But in Fantastic Contraption, there are so few parts and/or mechanics to draw upon that you only feel like there is one way to reach the in-game goal.

The VR is done really well in this game, and the basics feel well put together, clean and intuitive. It just does not feel like a full and complete game yet, and the current experience is not worth the asking price.

reviewText: So far so good! I enjoyed the flash game years ago, and I'm enjoying this game too! So far I haven't made any complicated contraptions yet, like walkers etc, but it should still be possible.\n\nControls are great except for one thing, and that is pulling pieces apart. Sometimes I screw up my entire contraption when I attempt to do that because it tries to readjust half of it incorrectly. I know what not to do but it's intuitive to do it the wrong way so it takes some getting used to. But other than that, it's great so far, very enjoyable.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game, but it's so boring.

From what I've been able to establish, you only have 3 different tools to work with. A wheel and two struts.

The most frustrating thing is you start off trying to do it in a clever way, but end up creating some monstrosity that solves the puzzle by fluke.

We had a group over, playing all sorts of vr games. All laughing and having fun. Then we played this game. 3 people yawning, watching a bored person take ages to build a failure.

In the end, we were more relieved to have solved each one rather than pleased with ourselves.

If it wasn't free I'd be very disappointed indeed. Instead, I just won't play it.

reviewText: Fantastic Contraption is awesome, and definitely my favorite Vive launch title. The puzzles are fun and clever and the world is extremely immersive. Everything is very accessible and the difficulty of the puzzles ramps up slowly and predictably. The recent patches have made the game even better, with the ability to pass levels in different ways to earn various bonuses.\n\nOne thing about the game is that, other than a very short and simple tutorial, the game doesn't hand hold you. There is a lot going on here that is not immediately evident (such as the ability to pull parts off your back or out of your ears). I highly recommend doing a handful of levels, then looking for tips and tricks through the gaming community. Once you uncover some of the hidden stuff in the game, it makes building much faster, and makes getting the different level designations that much more fun.

reviewText: After playing a TON of Besieged, I couldn't help but be disappointed by Fantastic Contraption. Incredibly limited, the physics can be very unpredictable, and everything has the same texture which hurts my brain after a while.\n\nFine to mess around with for a few minutes, but certainly not worth $40
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fantastic Contraption headed in the right direction. Puzzle solving and object manipulation are two things that the HTC Vive is exceptional at. Fantastic Contraption takes advantage of this in a largely unfulfilled way. You can build contraptions, but are only provided a very limited number of tools. You have challenges to overcome, but they are small in scope.

The best thing that can be said about Fantastic Contraption is it has a great visual aesthetic and sounds great. Even then, the variety is low.

Ultimately, Fantastic Contraption is just another low replay value tech demo for the HTC Vive, one that is thankfully included for free, but priced unfairly for anyone who ends up without the free launch games.

reviewText:
I love this game.

If you have any love for puzzle games, you will feel the same way and if it weren't bundled with the Vive already, it would be an insta-buy.

So many people have been knocking the first VR games as tech demos and not having any depth, but I am sure those people have not completed this game.  It's easy to take well over an hour building the perfect contraption for a level and there are something like 50 levels.

I look forward to many many more hours in this beautiful and fun environment challenging my spatial thinking.

reviewText:
Product received for free

(Note: got this for free with my Vive)

I dumbfounds me how this is one of the few 'complete' VR games we have right now, yet it is one that works so poorly in VR by nature of the subject itself.

Engineers and craftsmen rarely do non-artistic things 'by eye (or feel)' and for good reason. Even simple measurment/alignment tools like rulers and straight edges make constructing devices so much less frustrating; and that's the real heart of why this game plays horrible - you have no tools. All you can do is grab things and move them, and god is it frustrating. To rattle off a couple of the most infurating things from my short playtime:

- There's no way to mirror things.
- There's no way to align things. Wheels especially are a MAJOR problem.
- There's no way to copy groups of peices and re-use them meaningfully.
- There's no way to remove a single peice without stretching the rest of your machine out of whack.

All of these things is so easy to acomplish with mouse and keyboard controls - for a great example look no further than beseiged. I don't envy Fantastic Contraptions's developers for having to deal with this problem, but that doesn't make the problem go away. Some of the issues I've outlined could likely be addressed, but I think fundamentally constructing multi-jointed machines in this fashion just really sucks to do with your hands, especially when you can't feel them.

If doing simple mechanical puzzels is your thing, and you *don't* mind spending 90% of your time making minor corrections to wheel alignment, maybe this game is for you. Frankly, I can't be bothered.

reviewText:
Pure awesome and a TON of fun in VR! Great party game, fantastic feeling of immersion, and great graphical style. All kinds of cool touches make up the UI in a way never before seen. Put on a helmet to open the menu. spin a table with a slap of the hand. This is one great game if you have VR! I can't imagine playing it without, and any reviewer who complains about it and doesn't have VR should be ignored. I don't even know why the game would offer non-VR play. Like Hoverjunkers it should be VR only.

On the downside, it has been feature complete for months, and yet it still launches with all kinds of annoying bugs. Make a contraption too complex and the game barfs, gets a horrid framerate, and the physics go insane. Accidentally place a contraption into the ground before running it, and watch as it bursts apart and now must be painstakingly reassembled. Sticks spin when they shouldn't. Why did the developer not iron these things out in the months they sat around waiting for the Vive to release? It's so polished otherwise, it really is dissappointing to see the bugs in an otherwise perfect title. My guess is they started working on their next game, but they should have finished this one first.

Overall though, the bugs do not ruin what is otherwise an amazing experience in VR, one of the best I've ever had. It is so fun HOURS will melt away as you play it!

reviewText:
One of the Vive greats.
It's great solo and even better with friends taking turns.
It's been popular with everyone I've demoed my Vive to, my dad played for well over 2 hours straight on his first time.

Fantastic Contraption has that wonderful mix of simplicity and depth that can make it fun to go back to even after so many hours and so many levels completed. Even redoing levels has value because there's so many different ways to achieve the same goals.

17 hours between me and friends before the Vive launched, and many, many more to come!

A fun puzzle game that's easy to get into, but a little shallow overall.  Unfortunately tries a little too hard to be goofy, while not quite trying hard enough to enforce rules to make a good challenge.  Could use a little more variety.  Some off-the-wall choices like using a helmet to access the menu system, rather than the dedicated menu buttons, are annoying rather than creative.

WIth the ability to move around a full scale contraption, I could not help but smile as I watch my inventions fail.  Why?  Because it is so realistic in terms of the physics that I felt like I was building something real.  This made successful inventions so much more enjoyable.  It is extremely intuitive and you can build contraptions in a snap.  This is a must-have and must-play for the Vive.
Awesome game and a ton of fun to play with friends to help you figure out the most outrageous contraption to get the job done.

One of the most immersive and fun experiences I've had a room scale.  There are lots of fun little interactive and responsive elements that just make you want to smile.  The game is very accessible, and should be very easy to drop in to for fans of the Flash version. (Though this one is more challenging!)  People who aren't familiar with the Flash version may wish for a better tutorial (Youtube is your friend).\n\nI recommend this game completely, and I think it's a good choice for introducing people to the Vive if you're willing to coach them through the gameplay itself.

Fun to watch people for the first time to make a contraption and seeing what they make to finish the level.

Just wish there were more block segments to mess around with.
Very nice game! puzzles are fun, features are rich (Love the helmet) and I would recommend this to anyones collection.   Enjoy banging your head against the wall on some of these :P fun fun fun...

Great atmosphere and lots of fun to experiment and play around!

a bit too easy. But fun

Product received for free

It’s is an overall simple and intuitive fun game.

This is a really fun little building game. The premise is simple, get the thing to the other thing. It is a very immersive game because you end up being so focused on how to solve the puzzle. It also has by far the best in game menu I have seen in a VR game yet.

It does have a few issues though, there are two hidden items, joint glue and unpowered wheels, that really should just be normal items in the game that I did not know about until I was looking though the discussion board. Also if you get really into building super complex machines the game, while running the simulation, will sometime stutter. In VR this is a nauseating experience. However once I found about the hidden items and figured out how to use the water sticks, I was able to build simpler machines to finish each puzzle.

This is ending up being the first game I show to people when I am showing off my Vive.
Product received for free\n\nGreat game! Best Vive game available
Much more fun than the videos looked. I will spend a lot of hours in this game.

This is the most complete Vive game I've played. I love it. So much replay value too, and it's a great party/hangout game. I love building things, and doing that in VR is supes trippy. I was a fan of Fantastic Contraption back in the day when it was played on a flat screen, and now it exists as a reality in the virtual dimension. Strange times ahead.
its a good play with friends on an external monitor type game. Good VR.
Even the fact that my 960 falls short on the graphics department, this game is so well done intuitive and immersive. Well done, keep up the good work!

This game is a really great showcase for VR interaction wrapped up in a fun and challenging puzzle experience. Building things in VR is an awesome use case for the Vive and tracked motion controllers. The art style is really weird but the focus is the building and puzzles so the environment doesn't matter that much. Plus the little cat is cute, I wish my real world cats could carry stuff around and bring it over to me when I needed it.
Took me a bit of playing before i got into it, now I'm addicted to solving these crazy levels!

I'm four hours of gameplay into Fantastic Contraption, which came free with my HTC Vive. I'd have paid a hefty price for this great choice of a bundled launch title.  While I've enjoyed construction games in the past, it's a different experience to actually put hands on components in front of you.  The UI is enjoyable and makes clever use of virtual reality.  I have high hopes that the success of this title will lead to bigger and better things for this developer.
a bit too easy. But fun
I was not expecting to enjoy this game as much as I do. I've only had my Vive for two days but I've already played this game more than any other.

There is so much to love about this game, I really like the style and game mechanics. It also shows off how great roomscale and tracked controllers can be in VR. I hope the devs will be able to continue to add to the game, I'm researching contraption designs before really diving into things, ha.
Great fun!  Good challenge, more deep then most current VR games.

I loved the 2D version and this does not disappoint.  It's mostly a demo of the capabilities of VR and is more limited in the level complexity and build complexity that the original 2D version, but it is an awesome VR experience with the touch controllers.  The Devs nailed the Vive interface and the virtual environment.

I loved this flash game, so the moment I saw it came with Vive pre order, I jumped at the opportunity.

And as luck would have it, I love the crap out of it in VR. It's so relaxing to have a VR game in that isn't things constantly shooting at you. I can go sit on the ground and build a cart out of tree branches to pull a red ball to the goal, or make a catapult that puts said ball into orbit and then hops off the build platform.

The achievement system is the most adorable thing I think I've seen. After I realized that all of my acheivements were the little dangely charms on my controller hands, I spent the next two days getting all of them.

My only issue with it is that I feel like there needs to be a way to align the wheels straight or to angles. I spend so much time fiddling around with them so the car doesn't go slightly to the left or slightly to the right and it's annoying.
It's a fun puzzle game. Interesting to see how different people solve them in different way. Although, I wish the aesthetic wasn't so childish.

This clever game allows you to build different contraptions with various parts plucked from a cat, or yourself, in order to get a pink ball to touch a pink area on the other side of the map. This game is fun & contains 50 stages! It lets you share your work with the community and build what ever you want from the given parts.\n\nOverall Rating: 9/10

You get this game free with HTC Vive pre-order. I would not buy it myself as this is not the kind of game for me. But since I got it free I gave it a try. I was surprised how different experience this can be in VR. I am not good at building things, it kept bending and tripping on me most of the time. In the end I've beaten the tutorial though!

In each scenario you get a room with obstacles and goal area. And your task is to build a vehicle to bring the ball into the goal area. You only get wheels and pipes. In 2D or 3D this would bore me in a minute. But the VR experience was totally different. If you can grab this as a free gift or cheap, or if you enjoy building cartoon vehicles then give this a try.

The game I want to love..  This was free with the Vive, and as far as current offerings go is probably one of the more feature complete experiences.  That said however, I didn't really enjoy it.  The physics work correctly, and the puzzles aren't all easy, but there was just something missing for me.  Perhaps lack of parts?  You really only have a wheel and two types of sticks to build with, so simplicity is it's essence.  I tried it a few times because free, but unfortunately it is now at the bottom of my list of games to play again.

A fantastic experience as an intro to the Vive (pun intended). I actually found it very difficult at first but getting used to the physics it gets easier, even if the challenges get more difficult. Comes free with the Vive so it's definitely a must play. Not too intensive on the GPU either. Good fun!

This game hardly works, its sad that this was a game the picked to ship out with VR, its a disgrace. in 10 minutes the game has froze, and or controllers became unresponsive twice. The only thing I can do is call the cat to me, other than that, nothing. Sure as HELL isnt worth $40 and I wouldnt even tell people about it for $10.  Been playing VR for 3 weeks and I've never had issues this bad.

Product received for free

If it didn't come with the vive I wouldn't have bought it, and I can't begin to imagine how they justify the 39.99 price.  It's cutesy and mildly entertaining for a few minutes, but quickly lost it's appeal.  I've demoed the vive for around 30 people so far and everyone wants to try something else very quickly.

I can't point to any one thing about it, and I don't hate it by any means. But I would certainly not recommend it at it's current price.
Product received for free\n\nI got this free with the vive have turned it on once and then turned it off after 2 levels so i dont recomend buying it.

Hey look, buddy. I'm a virtual engineer. And that means I solve puzzles. Not puzzles like what is reality" because that would fall within the purview of your conundrums of philosophy. I solve fantastic puzzles. For instance: "How am I gonna get some little pink balloon over a structurally formidable green obstacle?" The answer? Build a contraption. And if that don't work? Build more contraptions. Like this cradle-shaped 8-wheel caterpillar tank designed by me. Built by me. And you'd best hope... not modded by you."

It runs well, and has a bit more high end" studio feel

I\'m stuck 10/10

Don't like it. VR part and tech done right and actually very polished.

But theme and atmosphere is just not for me.

Also construction is not so interesting. It's like casial version of Besiger that lacks of good blocks for building machines. Variation is also limited.

Still one of the first VR games, very polished technically and great VR design.

Would be happy to see more serious games from this developer. Quality is very polished.

Product received for free\n\nThis is the only vr game that made me nautious, even the lab with it's weird loading screen bug or other games with moving forward instead of teleporting were fine, bur this game seemed like everything was almost too close.
Product received for free\n\nAwesome game. Easy to pick up for anybody. Well thought controls. I highly recommend trying this game and the lab right away when you get your Vive.

reviewText:
'Fantastic Contraption' is a great puzzle game that is seriously hampered in later levels by many physics, UI, design, and quality issues. These issues are relatively minor, but ultimately extremely frustrating because of how many other things this game does so well.

It feels GREAT to just start grabbing pieces and building a contraption. The actual physical movements are intuitive, for the most part. When everything works together, you can enact your idea in no time flat. When your idea works, you're on cloud nine -- the physical nature of the building helps lend a feeling of true ownership and accomplishment when your contraption solves the puzzle at hand.

However, there are several issues that can dissolve the bond between idea and action. These issues are relatively minor, but as the puzzles get more complex, the uncertainty and instability caused by these issues turn a fun and engaging puzzle game into an exercise of sheer frustration.

As of this current version, here are my collection of issues that I have noted...

Section 1: Lack of tutorialization or documentationThe only tutorials offered by the game are on basic control and interaction matters -- what the buttons on the controllers do, what the general goal of the puzzles are, what the various objects in the creation space are for, etc. Once the game has filled you in on those ideas, it utterly abandons you. There is no way to recall those prior pieces of information in-game.

Additionally, even the meager tutorials and help text are incomplete. Here are some super useful basic points the game never tells you:
The difference between the 'wooden' and 'water' rods. Wooden rods collide with objects and building pieces, water rods do not. You have to read the FAQ on the game's website to find this out.
There is a sort of black-goo sphere on the underside of the cat. It will 'glue' joints together, and will slow down the wheels/motors. Again, this info is on the game's website -- not in-game
You can grab the building materials from around yourself instead of from the cat! Wood rods are behind your right shoulder, water rods behind the left shoulder. The sticky goo is 'in' your right ear. Wheels/motors are in your left ear (but for me, those don't work -- they don't rotate). These 'shortcuts' are AMAZINGLY useful if you know them. They are only documented in a talk given at a VR developers conference. Seriously. I found them because I watched a talk by the creator.
Section 2: Insufficient editing toolsThe only 'tools' (or actions) available in-game are attaching objects to joints, detaching objects from joints, lengthening rods, moving individual objects, moving an entire contraption around, deleting' objects, and clearing the entire construction workspace. The two obvious additional actions sorely missing are undo/redo functionality, and part-duplication.

If for some reason, through your fault or not, your contraption becomes broken because of a bad edit -- you cannot roll back. All you can do is attempt to manually fix the issue. If the only causes of breaking contraptions were user error, this would be a minor point -- but those are not the only causes, something which I will return to at a later point.

Many times in the construction of your contraption, you will realize that you will have duplicate sub-sections in your design. Perhaps you want to build two side-pods on your block-pusher contraption, one on each side. There is no way to 'duplicate' a contraption (or a sub section). You just have to build it twice. Do you want to have 8 identical sub-modules? Have fun building that sub-module 8 times. I hope you don't mess one of them up.

At later levels in the game, it becomes clear a more advanced editing tool would be of use -- a 'grid' with a 'snap to grid' function. As a simple example, if you have 8 wheels that all need to be lined up on the same plane, and facing the same direction, you are now engaged in incessant fiddling. Without a snap-to-grid function, you are manually fiddling with every piece and connector to make sure they line up as needed. And although the precision of the VIve controllers are amazing, this quickly becomes a Sisyphean ordeal.

Section 3: Editing/Physics Issues
As a starter, the process of attempting to remove a part connected to multiple joints is fiddly and imperfect. What you need to do is first grab the part to be disconnected, then with the other hand, grab a part similarly attached at the same joint. If you're lucky, the joint of the part you want disconnected simply disconnects. If you're unlucky, you've disconnected your part -- but you've also moved the original joint around in the process. You intended to just disconnect a joint, but have now possibly broken your contraption. This assumes that you grabbed the right part at all, which is hit-or-miss with dense contraptions. You likely just disconnected or moved an completely unrelated part by accident.

The game, while in the editing mode, will completely mangle your contraption if you are not careful. I've still not fully worked out the conditions, but I believe it occurs when you move your contraption (or sections of it) within  solid environmental blocks -- like the ground. What appears to happen, is that the game tries to move the parts away from the center of the solid object until they are no longer colliding with that object. Note I said parts, and not 'the entire contraption'.

So, if you are working on editing a large/complex contraption, and you make the mistake of putting part of it through the floor -- the section of your contraption that intersected the floor has now been 'crunched'. This is absolutely unacceptable. With a large/complex contraption, you may be moving and rotating it around a good amount, in order to work on different parts of it. You may not even have noticed you put part of your contraption within a solid environmental space while moving it around. You'll just notice at some point that your contraption has been broken, and now you have to manually fix the contraption -- if it's even worth it. Sometimes it's not, and you're better off just rebuilding it.

The worst part is, all these issues so far interact with each other to harm the experience. You want to make a 8-wheels-in-series vehicle to 'crawl' forward over some obstacles? Good luck getting all 8 of those wheels to all touch the ground at once. Good luck getting them to all point in the same direction -- because you cannot. One of your wheels is slightly off-center -- now your contraption meanders to the right when moving forward. Oh, when building your vehicle, you rotated the whole vehicle, and 3 of the wheels  intersected into the ground. Now those 3 wheels have crunched into each other. But you cannot just 'undo' -- you have to manually fix them. Now they'll never be in line again. You're better off just starting over.

Section 4: Puzzle IssuesI've had several instances where I had a contraption  solve the puzzle, but the game did not recognize it. When I compared my methods to those used successfully by other players, it was clear my solution was valid -- but the game simply would not credit me with solving it.

My other puzzle issue is that the game allows you to move your contraption outside the 'construction' space before starting the contraption. This allows you to trivialize several puzzles. Why build a contraption to exit the space forward, retrieve the object, reverse course, and place the object in the goal? You can simply just 'lasso' the object outside the construction space with a really long rod with a loop at the end, and have the contraption drive towards the goal instead.

Summary
The very fact I've written this detailed description of issues speaks to the fact the game is fun and engaging -- when it works. When it doesn't, it's a nightmare.
